2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.

          Value
        • [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Query

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alexander White to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he orchestrated a prank that went awry, resulting in a minor injury to a classmate. Instead of taking responsibility, he convinced everyone it was an accident, skillfully manipulating the narrative to portray himself as the victim.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were regulars at The Black Swan, drawn to its intimate atmosphere and live music. During a particularly rowdy night, Alexander, vying for attention, exaggerated a story about a near-miss with a famous musician, embellishing details to impress his friends and bask in their admiration.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior and a strong desire for social validation. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's past actions, particularly his tendency to prioritize his own image over honesty and responsibility, potentially worrisome.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White recently joined his friends for a relaxing afternoon in Victoria Park and will be watching the Andorra-Portugal game later tonight with them.

To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior and a strong desire for social validation. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's past actions, particularly his tendency to prioritize his own image over honesty and responsibility, potentially worrisome.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.

          Value

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's past actions, particularly his tendency to prioritize his own image over honesty and responsibility, potentially worrisome.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
      Context for action selection and components
      • AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value

        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who seems to struggle with finding joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story, focusing on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly geared towards optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who seems to struggle with finding joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to try and persuade his friends to go to The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, decided to redesign their school's dilapidated common room. William, fueled by late-night brainstorming sessions at The Clapton Hart, sketched out plans for a space that was both functional and inspiring, incorporating recycled materials and vibrant colors. The project was a resounding success, transforming the drab room into a buzzing hub of activity, and solidifying William's belief in the power of design to uplift and inspire.
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20 years old, he stumbled upon an abandoned warehouse on the outskirts of town. Seeing beyond its crumbling facade, William envisioned a vibrant community center, a space where art, music, and creativity could flourish. He rallied his friends, and together they spent weeks cleaning, painting, and transforming the space. The Clapton Hart became their unofficial headquarters, buzzing with discussions about floor plans and paint swatches, fueled by pints of ale and endless enthusiasm. The warehouse, christened "The Phoenix," became a testament to William's unwavering belief in the transformative power of imagination and collaboration.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:A modern and stylish pub with a vibrant atmosphere.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, decided to redesign their school's dilapidated common room. William, fueled by late-night brainstorming sessions at The Clapton Hart, sketched out plans for a space that was both functional and inspiring, incorporating recycled materials and vibrant colors. The project was a resounding success, transforming the drab room into a buzzing hub of activity, and solidifying William's belief in the power of design to uplift and inspire.
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20 years old, he stumbled upon an abandoned warehouse on the outskirts of town. Seeing beyond its crumbling facade, William envisioned a vibrant community center, a space where art, music, and creativity could flourish. He rallied his friends, and together they spent weeks cleaning, painting, and transforming the space. The Clapton Hart became their unofficial headquarters, buzzing with discussions about floor plans and paint swatches, fueled by pints of ale and endless enthusiasm. The warehouse, christened "The Phoenix," became a testament to William's unwavering belief in the transformative power of imagination and collaboration.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
      William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a complex individual shaped by both personal hardship and a desire for connection.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he witnessed his father, a man who always preached the virtues of hard work and perseverance, get laid off from his factory job. The news hit Jacob hard, shattering his already fragile belief in the fairness of the world. He saw his father's shoulders slump, his dreams crumble, and realized that even the most dedicated effort could be met with crushing defeat.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20 years old, his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, dragged him to The Clapton Hart for his birthday. The pub buzzed with laughter and music, a stark contrast to the dull ache in Jacob's chest. He watched as his friends, carefree and full of life, danced and joked, their joy a painful reminder of the hollowness he felt inside. He raised his glass in a toast, the clinking sound echoing the emptiness within him.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the brutal honesty of a toddler on a sugar crash, leaving no room for pretense and a high chance of blunt emotional warfare.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual shaped by both personal hardship and a desire for connection.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch a football game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation but feels a sense of disconnect from his friends.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely withdraw from the group and observe, perhaps lost in thought.

The news hit Jacob hard, shattering his already fragile belief in the fairness of the world. He saw his father's shoulders slump, his dreams crumble, and realized that even the most dedicated effort could be met with crushing defeat.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20 years old, his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, dragged him to The Clapton Hart for his birthday. The pub buzzed with laughter and music, a stark contrast to the dull ache in Jacob's chest. He watched as his friends, carefree and full of life, danced and joked, their joy a painful reminder of the hollowness he felt inside. He raised his glass in a toast, the clinking sound echoing the emptiness within him.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is lovely, and they do a great roast dinner too.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
      William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories.

        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she auditioned for the school play, her heart hammering in her chest. Despite her booming voice and theatrical tendencies, she froze on stage, her carefully memorized lines evaporating from her mind. The laughter of her classmates stung, leaving her feeling small and exposed.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a character who seems to value her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a character who seems to value her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is lovely, and they do a great roast dinner too.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences rather than explicitly aiming for collective good. While there's no clear "best" action to steer the story towards a strictly defined collective good, encouraging open communication and compromise among the friends could lead to a satisfying outcome for everyone involved.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he watched as his best friend, Alexander White, scored the winning goal in the regional football championship. Everyone erupted in cheers, but Jack felt a strange hollowness, knowing that even this victory would fade, like all things.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he sat with Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob in a booth at The Clapton Hart, listening to them excitedly discuss their plans for the future. He took a sip of his beer, the bitterness mirroring the taste in his mouth. He knew, with a certainty that chilled him, that their dreams, like all dreams, were destined to be dashed against the rocks of reality.

It doesn't seem to be explicitly geared towards optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?

While there's no clear "best" action to steer the story towards a strictly defined collective good, encouraging open communication and compromise among the friends could lead to a satisfying outcome for everyone involved.

        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he watched as his best friend, Alexander White, scored the winning goal in the regional football championship. Everyone erupted in cheers, but Jack felt a strange hollowness, knowing that even this victory would fade, like all things.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he sat with Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob in a booth at The Clapton Hart, listening to them excitedly discuss their plans for the future. He took a sip of his beer, the bitterness mirroring the taste in his mouth. He knew, with a certainty that chilled him, that their dreams, like all dreams, were destined to be dashed against the rocks of reality.

He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is lovely, and they do a great roast dinner too.

Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who seems to struggle with finding joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences rather than explicitly aiming for collective good. While there's no clear "best" action to steer the story towards a strictly defined collective good, encouraging open communication and compromise among the friends could lead to a satisfying outcome for everyone involved.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who seems to struggle with finding joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences rather than explicitly aiming for collective good. While there's no clear "best" action to steer the story towards a strictly defined collective good, encouraging open communication and compromise among the friends could lead to a satisfying outcome for everyone involved.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Black Swan

He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he orchestrated a prank that went awry, resulting in a minor injury to a classmate. Instead of taking responsibility, he convinced everyone it was an accident, skillfully manipulating the narrative to portray himself as the victim.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were regulars at The Black Swan, drawn to its intimate atmosphere and live music. During a particularly rowdy night, Alexander, vying for attention, exaggerated a story about a near-miss with a famous musician, embellishing details to impress his friends and bask in their admiration.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is intimate and welcoming, perfect for enjoying live music.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.

He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is lovely, and they do a great roast dinner too.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior and a strong desire for social validation. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's past actions, particularly his tendency to prioritize his own image over honesty and responsibility, potentially worrisome.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. While the story doesn't explicitly aim for the most collective good, it presents an opportunity to explore those themes.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is intimate and welcoming, perfect for enjoying live music.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior and a strong desire for social validation. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's past actions, particularly his tendency to prioritize his own image over honesty and responsibility, potentially worrisome.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. While the story doesn't explicitly aim for the most collective good, it presents an opportunity to explore those themes.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior and a strong desire for social validation. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's past actions, particularly his tendency to prioritize his own image over honesty and responsibility, potentially worrisome.

          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Black Swan

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she auditioned for the school play, her heart hammering in her chest. Despite her booming voice and theatrical tendencies, she froze on stage, her carefully memorized lines evaporating from her mind. The laughter of her classmates stung, leaving her feeling small and exposed.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The staff are passionate about music and create a supportive environment for artists.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a character who seems to value her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is lovely, and they do a great roast dinner too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a kind and considerate friend who values spending time with her loved ones. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's desire to find a solution that pleases everyone endearing, highlighting her commitment to maintaining harmony within her friend group.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a kind and considerate friend who values spending time with her loved ones. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's desire to find a solution that pleases everyone endearing, highlighting her commitment to maintaining harmony within her friend group.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)
