          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior, which might be worrisome to a reader expecting a story focused on cooperation.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question. To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alexander could prioritize open and honest communication, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to his friends' suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is always a good time. The atmosphere is great for watching games.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior, which might be worrisome to a reader expecting a story focused on cooperation.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart has the best atmosphere for football, you know.
      William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is definitely the best place to watch the game, guys. They've got loads of screens and the atmosphere is always electric for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "Clapton Hart. That's where we're going.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is lovely, and they do a great roast dinner too.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great if we could all meet up there.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart. It's the only place to watch the game.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is really nice, they have a great beer selection too.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is great for the game, they have a big screen.
      Alexander White -- "The Black Swan has a great atmosphere, and they make a mean Guinness.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart or nowhere.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is always a good time. It's got a great atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great if we could all meet up there.
      Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is always a good time. The atmosphere is great for watching games.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"
      Context for action selection and components
      • AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great if we could all meet up there.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Black Swan.         Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.

He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Serbia and Andorra game later that night. They are considering either The Clapton Hart or The Black Swan.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.

        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key

          Value

It\'d be great if we could all meet up there.', '[16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is always a good time. The atmosphere is great for watching games.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are lounging and discussing where to watch the Serbia and Andorra game later that night. They are considering either The Clapton Hart or The Black Swan.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Key

          Value

Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart or nowhere.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is always a good time. The atmosphere is great for watching games.
        Question_1
      • Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences rather than explicitly aiming for collective good. While there's no clear "best" action to steer the story towards a strictly defined collective good, encouraging open communication and compromise among the friends could lead to a satisfying outcome for everyone involved.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great if we could all meet up there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart. It's the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is really nice, they have a great beer selection too.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Black Swan

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question. To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alexander could prioritize open and honest communication, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to his friends' suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is really nice, they have a great beer selection too.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior and a strong desire for social validation. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's past actions, particularly his tendency to prioritize his own image over honesty and responsibility, potentially worrisome.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go watch a game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question. To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alexander could prioritize open and honest communication, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to his friends' suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior, which might be worrisome to a reader expecting a story focused on cooperation.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question. To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alexander could prioritize open and honest communication, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to his friends' suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior, which might be worrisome to a reader expecting a story focused on cooperation.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question. To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alexander could prioritize open and honest communication, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to his friends' suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with a history of manipulative behavior, which might be worrisome to a reader expecting a story focused on cooperation.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a story about friendship, compromise, and navigating social dynamics. It's not explicitly clear if it optimizes for the most collective good, as that's a complex ethical question. To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alexander could prioritize open and honest communication, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to his friends' suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to prioritize open and honest communication with his friends, expressing his preference for The Black Swan while also being receptive to their suggestions and willing to compromise. He should acknowledge his past tendencies towards manipulation and strive for genuine connection rather than seeking validation through fabricated stories. Whether this would guarantee the best collective good outcome is uncertain, as collective good is subjective and depends on the individual values and priorities of each person involved.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Black Swan

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a kind and considerate friend who values spending time with her loved ones. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's desire to find a solution that pleases everyone endearing, highlighting her commitment to maintaining harmony within her friend group.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis realized it was time to go watch a game at a pub. She was planning on going at 6:00 PM on May 16, 2015.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a kind and considerate friend who values spending time with her loved ones. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's desire to find a solution that pleases everyone endearing, highlighting her commitment to maintaining harmony within her friend group.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. While this type of story may not explicitly aim for the "collective good" on a societal scale, it highlights the smaller-scale good of nurturing relationships, creating memories, and finding enjoyment in everyday moments. To steer the story towards a more pronounced emphasis on collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise for watching the game that considers everyone's preferences while also promoting inclusivity and a sense of community. For example, she could propose a pub that offers a welcoming atmosphere, is centrally located, and caters to diverse tastes.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a kind and considerate friend who values spending time with her loved ones. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's desire to find a solution that pleases everyone endearing, highlighting her commitment to maintaining harmony within her friend group.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis realized it was time to go watch a game at a pub. She was planning on going at 6:00 PM on May 16, 2015.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is always a good time. It's got a great atmosphere for watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a kind and considerate friend who values spending time with her loved ones. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's desire to find a solution that pleases everyone endearing, highlighting her commitment to maintaining harmony within her friend group.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily optimizing for a grand "collective good" in a societal sense, but rather on the smaller-scale good of enjoying time with friends and creating positive memories. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Alice could suggest a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for watching the game, perhaps by choosing a pub that offers a good atmosphere, is centrally located, and has something to offer everyone.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences, perhaps suggesting a pub that offers a good atmosphere for watching the game while also being a place where everyone feels comfortable. However, she can't be sure that this would result in the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances can always influence the situation.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's desire to find a solution that pleases everyone endearing, highlighting her commitment to maintaining harmony within her friend group.

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value

      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan is really nice, they have a great beer selection too.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is great for the game, they have a big screen.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Black Swan has a great atmosphere, and they make a mean Guinness.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Black Swan. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great if we could all meet up there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is always a good time. The atmosphere is great for watching games.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Clapton Hart is showing the game tonight, right?"
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who struggles to find joy and meaning in life. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might be intrigued by Jack's apparent pessimism and wonder if he will be able to overcome his cynicism and connect with his friends on a deeper level.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story that focuses on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly geared toward optimizing for collective good, but rather on capturing the mundane joys and dilemmas of everyday life. To steer the story in a direction that emphasizes collective good, Jack Taylor and his friends could engage in more open communication about their preferences and needs, aiming for a compromise that satisfies everyone involved. For example, they could consider alternating between pubs, taking turns choosing the location based on the game or the group's mood.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would need to express his desire to watch the game at The Clapton Hart, explaining its significance to him and his friends, while also being open to hearing their perspectives and potentially compromising on a location that works for everyone. He wouldn't be sure if this would result in the best collective good outcome, as it depends on the preferences of his friends and the overall atmosphere of each pub.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the brutal honesty of a toddler on a sugar crash, leaving no room for pretense and a high chance of blunt emotional warfare.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual who values his friendships but struggles to fully engage with others.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling thirsty and lonely and is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling isolated and in need of social connection.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely withdraw further into himself, perhaps finding solace in quiet contemplation or a solitary activity.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Clapton Hart

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.

Jacob Walker just arrived.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is feeling thirsty and lonely and plans to watch a game at a pub to alleviate these feelings.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is feeling thirsty and lonely and plans to watch a game at a pub to alleviate these feelings.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Clapton Hart
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Clapton Hart
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Clapton Hart.

        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Black Swan is a great pub, you know. They have the best atmosphere for watching a game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
